transcript.title: Barnhart v. Sigmon Coal Company, Inc.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: submitted We'll hear argument next in Number oh oh thirteen oh seven, Larry Massanari, As- Acting Commissioner of Social Security versus the Sigmon Coal Company.
Mr. Wolfson.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
Congress enacted the Coal Act to prevent the collapse of a multi employer, private health care system that had promised health care benefits to retired coal miners.

Miners were in danger of losing their benefits as coal operators were selling their operations and dissolving and going out of business and shifting responsibility for their employees to other employers that were in the multi employer health care system.
Congress enacted the Coal Act to stop this downward spiral.

It wanted to ensure that a retired miner's benefits would be the responsibility of the operator that employed the miner, if possible, or if that operator was defunct, with one of that operator's related persons.
Section ninety-seven oh one C two of the Coal Act effectuates this policy.
That section sets forth the related persons who may be assigned responsibility for a miner's emp- for an operator's employees.
Under a straightforward reading of that statutory language in section ninety-seven oh one C two, the commissioner may assign a miner to the direct successor in interest of a signatory operator.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May I just clarify one point in response to Ju- your answer to Justice Ginsburg? You do agree, do you not, that even though this sale was an asset sale, that we are dealing with a successor in interest of a signatory here, within the meaning of ninety-seven oh one C?
As the commissioner has defined it, that issue as to whether...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, the term successor, at least in this statute, includes a purchaser that at an at an asset sale as well as a purchaser of stock.
No, Your Honor, e- it doesn't necessarily include that.
commissioner has taken.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: conceded that you are success- your client is a suc- c- successor in interest of a s- signatory operator?
As as the commissioner...
has, well,
Well, i- the issue is not before the Court.
is used.
there are statutes that...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: define successor in interest to include a kind of an asset sale.

Exactly, Judge Ginsburg, and that's why it would be remanded for further determinations, although the Williams Mountain court, the the DC the District of Columbia Circuit several months ago in the case of Williams Mountain did define that term to they didn't give it a specific definition, but they said it's somewhere between a tax code successor and the Black's Law Dictionary common law successor, which does not include asset...
purchasers.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you cannot fairly have it both ways.
We would not rely on the dictionary act as having any relevance on remand.
left to the dictionary act...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: successor liability in a way that you've been nu- unable to explain makes any sense whatsoever, that there's no reason to impose successor liability on the successor of a related person, while not imposing it on a successor of a signatory.
It doesn't, the statute does not impose liability on successors.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Successors of related persons.
No, sir.
expand to...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You're suggesting there's a difference between successor in interest and successor.
Yes, I I I believe...
there is a difference.
Well, typically if you look at the Black's Law Dictionary or the common law application of successor in interest, it is statutory succession, merger, name change successors, and so forth.
the commissioner even had adopted that definition.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: assume it only refers to s- s- a limited class.
Well, it it really I don't know the reason for that.
There...
other than the the notation this morning by the Solicitor General, there we weren't aware that the commissioner had ever made...
an assignment of liability.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that statement in in your...
brief was inaccurate.
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that merely emphasizes the incongruity of the statute.

I don't think so, with all due respect, because what what happened or or what is a plausible scenario is that we have fifty years of retroactivity in commercial transactions that have occurred in the coal industry.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But if I understand the definition of related persons, it could cover p- people not even in the coal business at all...
and their successors in interest.
the thing about that definition is and the reason it has some logic to expanding liability is it does encompass entities that have an economic connection with the employer.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I do I do have one question on on on the basic statutory point, the s- the shoehorning question of whether or not Shackleford is is is described in the statute.
No, it was not.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, then s- Roman One would not apply.
That's correct. There are a ton of others...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Shackleford had been a member of a controlled group of corporations, then it might have been included in the controlled group and then it might have been described.

Which is the problem with the commissioner's linguistic gymnastics in trying to say that the the commissioner's definition in that case would basically mean that there's always a control group because one is always related to himself.
case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: been a member of a controlled group, not a group of one, that argument would have been slightly more plausible, it seems to me.
I don't think it would be any more...
plausible through the language.
Exactly.
And i-, but i-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: When I talk about Shackleford, I mean the first Shackleford.
That's correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Because if it had been, I think the commissioner would have had a better argument, and it would still have the problem of being related to yourself.
We would still have all the linguistic problems with with...
describing...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: think all because it is the word there is include...
It's...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: in o- one.
Well, it it's not applicable here.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I know you've discounted the significance of the legislative history, ju- the Senator's comment and so forth.
The the jurisprudence of this Court is that the language of the statute controls when it's clear.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Even if it's perfectly clear Congress intended otherwise.
Yes.
I guess the answer is that...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the only way it it can be perfectly clear that Congress intended otherwise is for both houses of Congress, not a single committee of one Congress, to have enacted the provision.
Exactly.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: perfectly clear that both houses intended otherwise.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It would make it perfectly clear to Justice Scalia.
It it it it...
it makes it makes for a a rational jurisprudence when one tends to enforce the the language that's actually in the statute.
enactment of this act.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: makes it so anomalous to impose successor liability on successors of re- related persons who don't have anything to do with the coal industry.

But if but if that question comes to the Court, the Court will have to deal with that question as to whether that is liability that may be enforced and imposed on such distantly related entities for historic transactions under the same criteria that the Court used, for example, in the Eastern Enterprises case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Of course, these people were distant not only from the transactions in question but also from the negotiations that produced the statute.
Exactly.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And and that may well be the ex- explanation of why they got stuck.

Yes, if they weren't there to represent their interests, then a- and they likely weren't since, I don't think, anybody that is that distance, distantly related would ha- have even been aware that there was a problem in funding benefits.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But, of course, here there's no doubt about the fact that whoever is covered it was intended to be the statute was intended to have retroactive effect.
Yes. It is it is retroactive to everyone that is covered.

The final point is that if this language is enforced as written, the benefits are going to be provided to the Shackleford beneficiaries on a pro rata basis by all the operators who are assigned liability, including Jericol, to the extent it o- it otherwise has valid liability for people that it did employ.
will receive their benefits for a long...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: funding has been adequate thus far.
Yes, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Mr. Woodrum.
Mr. Wolfson, you have half a minute remaining.
Don't use it all in...
Very briefly.
Thank you, Mr. Wolfson.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The case is submitted.
The honorable court is now adjourned until Tuesday the thirteenth of November at ten o'clock.
